key_insight: The paper introduces a psychometric testing framework that reliably measures and validates personality-like traits in large, instruction-tuned LLMs and shows those trait profiles can be reproduced or steered in downstream tasks. Instruction tuning improves measurement consistency, enabling both evaluation and controlled persona shaping.
problem_solved: Lack of principled, validated methods to quantify, validate and manipulate personality-like traits in LLMs — making comparisons, audits, and purposeful persona design unreliable or ad hoc.
method: Adapt established psychometric instruments (e.g., standardized personality questionnaires) into promptable tests for LLMs and collect model responses.
Statistically validate measurements (reliability, consistency across prompts/sampling, factor structure) to confirm traits are robustly measured in instruction-tuned models.
Demonstrate shaping by conditioning, prompting, or downstream fine-tuning to reproduce target personality profiles and evaluate task-level effects.
impact: Provides AI/ML practitioners with a validated toolkit to evaluate, compare and intentionally design model personas—improving interpretability, alignment, personalization and auditability of LLM behavior. It bridges human psychometrics and model evaluation for safer, more controllable deployments.
visual_elements: Flowchart: prompt → LLM response → scoring pipeline → psychometric analysis (reliability & factor checks).
Bar/line chart: reliability and consistency scores across model families and instruction-tuning conditions.
Radar (spider) plots: side-by-side personality profiles for baseline vs. shaped models.
Schematic: downstream task performance when applying different induced personality profiles (cause → effect).
paper_title: A psychometric framework for evaluating and shaping personality traits in large language models
paper_authors: Gregory Serapio-García, Mustafa Safdari, Clément Crepy, Luning Sun, Stephen Fitz
